verses.verse: ((1 To the intent he might move the faithful to deeper consideration of God’s glory, he setteth before their eyes the most exquisite workmanship of the heavens, with their proportion, and ornaments.8 And afterward calleth them to the Law, wherein God hath revealed himself more familiarly to his chosen people. The which peculiar grace by commending the Law, he setteth forth more at large.) ) The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament showeth the work of his hands.
(The continual success of the day and the night is sufficient to declare God’s power and goodness.) Day unto day uttereth the same, and night unto night teacheth knowledge.
There is no speech nor (The heavens are a Schoolmaster to all nations, be they never so barbarous.) language, where their voice is not heard.

Their (The heavens are as a line of great capital letters to show unto us God’s glory.) line is gone forth through all the earth, and their words into the ends of the world: in them hath he set a tabernacle for the Sun.

Which cometh forth as a bridegroom out of his (Or veil. The manner was that the bride and bridegroom should stand under a veil together, and after come forth with great solemnity, and rejoicing of the assembly.) chamber, and rejoiceth like a mighty man to run his race.
His going out is from the end of the heaven, and his compass is unto the ends of the same, and none is hid from the heat thereof.

The (Though the creatures cannot serve, yet this ought to be sufficient to lead us unto him.) Law of the Lord is perfect, converting the soul: the testimony of the Lord is sure, and giveth wisdom unto the simple.
The statutes of the Lord are right, and rejoice the heart, the commandment of the Lord is pure, and giveth light unto the eyes.

The fear of the Lord is clean, and endureth forever: the judgments of the Lord are (So that all man’s inventions and intentions are lies.) truth: they are righteous (Everyone without exception.) altogether,
And more to be (Except God’s word be esteemed above all worldly things, it is contemned.) desired than gold, yea, than much fine gold: sweeter also than honey, and the honeycomb.
Moreover by them is thy servant made circumspect, and in keeping of them there is great (For God accepteth our endeavor, though it be far imperfect.) reward.
Who can understand his (Then there is no reward of duty, but of grace: for where sin is, there death is the reward.) faults? cleanse me from secret faults.

Keep thy servant also from (Which are done purposely and of malice.) presumptuous sins: let them not reign over me: (If thou suppress my wicked affections by thine holy spirit.) so shall I be upright, and made clean from much wickedness.
Let the words of my mouth, and the (That I may obey thee in thought, word and deed.) meditation of mine heart be acceptable in thy sight, O Lord my strength, and my redeemer.
